title: Felicity Huffman spends first night behind bars as she starts jail sentence
text:

Felicity Huffman has turned herself in to US authorities to start serving a jail sentence for her part in the college admissions scandal.

The Desperate Housewives was sentenced to 14 days behind bars after pleading guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit mail fraud and honest services mail fraud.

The charges stemmed from accusations the telly star paid a $15,000 bribe to boost her daughter’s SAT score to get her into an elite college.

According to TMZ.com , Huffman, 56, arrived at the Federal Correctional Institution in Dublin, California on Tuesday.

The website reports the movie star's first meal behind bars will be a chicken patty, steamed rice, beans and fruit, while Tuesday night's menu boasted pepper steak or lentils with steamed rice, green beans and whole wheat bread.

(Image: CJ GUNTHER/EPA-EFE/REX)

As well as her two weeks in jail, Huffman also got a $30,000 fine, 250 community service and a year of supervised release after she gets out.

Back in April, the actress confirmed she would be admitting the charges.

She said: "I am pleading guilty to the charge brought against me by the United States Attorney's Office.

"I am in full acceptance of my guilt, and with deep regret and shame over what I have done.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

"I accept full responsibility for my actions and will accept the consequences that stem from those actions.

"I am ashamed of the pain I have caused my daughter, my family, my friends, my colleagues and the educational community.

"I want to apologise to them and, especially, I want to apologise to the students who work hard every day to get into college...

And to their parents who make tremendous sacrifices to support their children and do so honestly."

She is among 12 other parents and a coach who have decided to plead guilty to charges in what has been dubbed Operation Varsity Blues.

Prosecutors reportedly recommended she spend up to a year in prison, but the sentence was eventually reduced to just two weeks.
